title: Meet and Eat
description: Time to kick off camp! Join us for some snacks and getting to know your fellow campers!

title: Arduino 101
description: Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the “Hello, Arduino” session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output.

title: Pop-up books and paper circuits
description: Pop-up engineering is really fun and extremely satisfying – for adults and for kids. But how might we use electricity to change the idea of what “interactive” books can be? In this session, participants will create pop-up cards that use the affordances of our materials to really investigate how circuits can change the idea of what a book can be. We’ll also consider where soft circuits are going by looking at examples in toys and wearable technologies.

title: Shop Safety!
description: Get Shop certified!

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.
comment: Sitting in on the first part of this workshop; thanks!

title: VJ demo/workshop
description: Since there are so many tools being presented at camp I’d like to demo a few ways to make them talk to one another. How can you bring a visualization sketch you wrote in Processing into MAX/MSP/Jitter or VDMX? Syphon! How can you control multiple applications at once from a touch screen? TouchOSC! My experience in using these devices and programs is derived from VJing (can we come up with a better term, please?) So we can talk about that, too. I think a fair amount of time at the end will be dedicated to a discussion about using the Kinect’s raw depth data, but we will not talk about OpenNI as I have no experience with that.

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

title: Quantified Self: Tools, Trends, and Applications
description: When Forbes called 2013 “the year of the Quantified Self” at CES it became clear that this is no longer a niche field just for life loggers. In this session I will go through the history of the quantified self (QS) movement, the existing apps/devices available, ways to hack together your own tools, trends in the industry, and discuss areas that are still untouched by this phenomenon that seems to be the new buzz word of 2013. A year and a half ago my life changed when I began tracking what I ate and how I felt, eventually leading me to cut gluten and dairy out of my diet. Since then I have become immersed in the QS field, helping to co-organize numerous Quantified Self Meetups here in NY, experimenting with dozens of QS tools/apps, and hacking together numerous quantified self tools of my own and in groups with others. By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of the existing QS landscape, be aware of industries ripe for QS development, and be primed with some easy ways to hack together their own projects and tools.

title: Dying Hungry: Learning to write from lede construction
description: “As Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from uneasy dreams he found himself transformed in his bed into a monstrous vermin.”

title: Introduction to the Arduino Yún
description: So you want to network your microcontroller. These days, you’ve got a lot of options. Here’s the latest from Arduino, the Yún. This board has the heart of an Arduino Leonardo attached to a WiFi-equipped Linux processor.
comment: I supported this microRF Arduino project on Kickstarter that is supposed to ship in July: http://www.rfduino.com/ I am a newbie but was hoping to build something with it.  Can someone tell me the advantages/disadvantages of Yun vs. RFduino? Thanks!

title: Github
description: What will the session cover?

title: Conductive Lace Making
description: Crochet, knitting, bobbin lace — join this session if you want to explore possibilities of lace as conductive material and if you want to learn basics of lacemaking.
comment: Very much looking forward to this!

title: Build a music visualizer from scratch in Processing
description: So!  Sunday night, after you’ve hacked some wearables, get down and dirty with an excellent intermediate level processing session on crafting a music visualizer.  I find it’s easiest to learn how to do something new when you have a project to try it with, so lets make a music visualizer!

title: Intro to Kinect & Processing
description: more to come but…
comment: Is it possible to sit in and watch this class?

title: Simple Animations for Digital Narratives
description: Part 3 of 3 in a series of sessions that provide a framework for creating narratives in the form of mobile apps.
comment: Hooray – attending for part of the time.

title: Film Cutting, Knot Tying, and The Ethics of Storytelling
description: In this participatory lecture, we will discuss the ethics behind story telling in interactive/immersive documentary, while cutting film and learning how to tie knots.

title: OpenNI Kinect with Osculator, Max/Jitter, Processing, Ableton Live etc
description: 10am – 12 (some calendars are showing 11am for some reason)

title: Fathers Day 3D Scanning Portrait Studio
description: Hey Dads!
comment: I’d like to bring my dad, if he’s able to travel.

title: Rest Of You: Digital Edition
description: Life is what happens to you will you are busy doing other things.  You pay attention to a small part of your experience when it is the rest of you that is more important.  The Rest of You is a class about trying to get a better picture of those parts that you don’t pay attention to.  This session will zero in on one week of work in the Rest Of You class that tries to cull through your digital footprint to give you a more accurate picture of yourself and perhaps suggest some interventions to change the rest of you.    Here are some assignments from the digital week of this class http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/roy/?cat=12

title: ITP Thesis Spotlight
comment: attending for part of the time; thanks.

title: Guest Speaker: Clive Thompson – “the new literacies”
Akimitsu Sadoi – LED Artist Workshop
description: Aki has offered to do a build workshop which should be quite fun and you’ll have something to take with you. It’s the simplest circuit with the least number of components (see image below). Yet it does share the same technical principle (multiplex LED drive with PWM) with more complex designs of his. He also think it’s a good material to get started with surface mount soldering.
comment: I am attending as well.  Sign me up for supplies.

title: Hacking the Kinect skeleton into Processing – follow- up
description: This is an informal follow-up to the OpenNI in Osculator, Max Jitter Ableton class.

title: Jitter-centric Weenie roast
description: A bunch of people have asked for some specialized help with Max/Jitter to supplement the intro sessions Gabe and I have run. However, there’s little consensus on what people want to get out of it. Requests have come in for OpenGL help, video tracking, and affirmation of life goals.
comment: I’ll be attending Robbie’s workshop earlier in the afternoon as well. I need help with video tracking.  I’ll be working with the Kinect unless it seems like another solution would be better.  Idea: taking an image or video; user bows (or performs other trackable function); doing it “correctly” triggers one video or still; doing in “incorrectly” triggers another video or still.

title: Zero to Plastic Part 2: 3D Scanning with ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models.

title: Collaborative Mobile Design for International Development
description: The world has nearly as many cell phone subscriptions as inhabitants, and 75% of them are in the developing world, with Africa leading the way. As the majority of mobile phone users live in emerging markets and developing economies, how do we design collaboratively with their needs, cultures and dreams in mind? How can mobile phone apps change informal economies and what goes into design considerations? How can we work together to improve billions of lives?

title: Designing Projections for a Chamber Opera
description: I recently created video projections for “Lotus Lives,” a new independent one-hour opera written for two singers, a brass quintet, percussion, and audio-video playback. I tackled everything from content design and creation, through coordinating six projectors with a live performance on a limited budget, and making sure it ran smoothly.

title: End-of-Camp Shindig
description: Half show & tell, half party, the End of Camp Shindig is an opportunity to celebrate the month we’ve spent together and share what we’ve created.
comment: Looking forward to it.  Can I bring two guests?
